Message.Title: didn't back fire yet
Message.Msg: Amazon's Anti-Apple Ad Backfires By Quentin Fottrell Negative advertisements seem to work better on voters than consumers. Earlier this week, Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) released--then pulled--an ad on its home page that portrayed Apple Inc.'s (AAPL) new iPad Mini as vastly inferior to its own Kindle Fire HD. The ad ran through the a feature-by-feature critique of the new $329Apple gadget, which went on sale Friday, and quoted a stinging review by technology site Gizmodo: "You're cramming a worse screen in there, charging more, and accusing others of compromise?" Like many campaign ads, the criticisms didn't stand up to fact-checking. Unlike the Mini, the $199 Fire does have a high-definition screen. But Amazon's comparison chart also claimed the Mini had a "mono speaker." In fact, the iPad Mini has a stereo speaker, an Apple spokeswoman says. (Amazon didn't respond to requests for comment.) The advertisement wasn't only a bad call because of the error, analysts say, but also because Amazon cherry-picked just a few technical specs for comparison. "It's probably too aggressive, given that we don't see the attack ad out there anymore," said Yung Trang, president of deal-aggregator site TechBargains.com. Consider, for example: The iPad Mini has two cameras, while the Kindle Fire HD has just one. Apple also has more than 700,000 apps; Kindle Store has less than 58,000 apps. "Amazon's comparison is selective at best, in order to paint the Kindle Fire HD in the best light," Mr. Trang said. (Just a week earlier, Amazon sent a survey to customers asking questions about a slew of technical questions regarding the features of the iPad Mini.) Of course, others say Amazon is right to use its heavily trafficked website for advertisements targeting

Topic.Title: Today's reversal in the entire market on an 'upbeat' jobs report jist goes to show you that

Message.Msg: no offense, but you shouldn't be just looking at jobs report, especially after the adp fiasco. Major revision on methodology makes the whole thing look bad. PMI globally was terrible. Gold didn't enjoy yesterday's rally, and neither did euro. very suspect. jobs numbers is one part of a big machine, and if the other cogs aren't spinning you are walking into a bull trap. cash is king right now. Trading is for prop firms and manipulators, wait and see instead of playing in traffic, the way down is much steeper than the way up if the bernanke commodities bubble is not resilient. POP.

Topic.Title: Today's reversal in the entire market on an 'upbeat' jobs report jist goes to show you that

Message.Msg: I don't think Einhorn is behind this (although it would be par for the course -- I'm always ahead of the curve and have to absorb significant pain to profit on these and he always seems to come in at just the right time to break it -- based on the same fundamental issues). I think institutional longs understand that they must slowly let these scams die else retail will never return. In the process, the are killing all the predatory MOMO funds.

Topic.Title: Today's reversal in the entire market on an 'upbeat' jobs report jist goes to show you that

Message.Msg: There is a thread connecting all that are down and going further down. Most deserve it. Some (like AAPL) don't. But, many funds will be liquidating assets soon and will be doing so at a big discount to current valuation. UST bonds might be a bubble long term, but anyone trying to devalue your capital is going to have to truly fight the Fed. The Fed isn't in it to preserve scam valuations that undermine the trust and credibility of the financial system, no matter what the pumpers on this board believe...
